column2: Has had their tarot read in the past year
The Moon (Upright)
The upright Moon arcana represents unconciousness, illusions, and intuition.
The Moon (Reversed)
The reversed Moon arcana represents confusion, fear, and misinterpretation.
The Star (Upright)
The upright Star arcana represents hope, faith, and rejuvenation.
The Star (Reversed)
The reversed Star arcana represents faithlessness, discouragement, and insecurity.
The Wheel of Fortune (Upright)
The upright Fortune arcana represents change, the inevitable, and fate.
The Wheel of Fortune (Reversed)
The reversed Fortune arcana represents no control, clinging to control, and bad luck.
The Tower (Reversed)
The reversed Tower arcana represents disaster avoided, delayed disaster, or fear of suffering.
The Hanged Man (Upright)
The upright Hanged Man arcana represents sacrifice, release, or martyrdom.
The Hanged Man (Reversed)
The reversed Hanged Man arcana represents stalling, needless sacrifice, or fear of sacrifice.
Tarot Reading
Visit the Hall of Wizardry and get your future told by the local astrologian.\nThe results may be §Ggood§! or §Rbad§!.
LF - The Astrologian

You are swiftly escorted to the tallest room in the tower by one of the apprentices, and soon left alone. Inside is a spacious room that resembles less of an mage study and more of a library. Only a table in front of you is any sign that this room could be used for research. Sitting in a tucked-away corner of the room is a beautiful elven woman, dressed in little more than sleepwear, surrounded by a multitude of cats.

  "I assume you have come to have your future foretold?" the woman asks in a warm voice. She motions toward the empty chair by the table. "Please, sit. I must warn you that there is no escaping fate, and whatever future I foretell is written in stone."

  Her warm smile fades and changes into an almost sinister smirk as a deck of cards levitates before her. "All I ask is a paltry sum of fifty coins."
Please tell my future.
Erm... I'll come back later.
LF - Luck of the Draw
This is good. Thank you.
Oh no...
Interesting.

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Moon in the upright position," she casually exclaims. "The Moon in the upright position symbolizes your imagination is taking the best of you. In the dark of the night, you are taking a path that you are unsure of, for there could be danger lurking in its depths. The moon's light can bring you clarity and understanding and you should allow your intuition to guide you through this darkness."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Moon in the reversed position," she casually exclaims. "The Moon in the reversed position indicates that the darker and more negative aspects of the moon are present in your life. It could represent confusion and unhappiness - you want to make progress, but you are not sure what is the right thing to do. You must deal with your anxiety and fears by overcoming them, for they are like shadows in the dark."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Sun in the upright position," she casually exclaims. "The Sun in the upright position represents success, abundance, and radiance. Like the sun itself, it gives strength and vitality to all those that are lucky enough to feel its rays. There is much joy and happiness that is coming to you."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Sun in the reversed position," she casually exclaims. "The Sun in the reversed position tells me that you might have significant difficulties finding positive aspects to certain situations. The clouds might be blocking out the warmth and light that you need to progress. This might be preventing you from feeling confident and powerful. You may experience certain setbacks which are damaging your optimism and enthusiasm."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Star in the upright position," she casually exclaims. "The Star in the upright position brings hope, renewed power, and strength to carry on with life. It shows how abundantly blessed you are by the universe as evidenced by the various things around you. It may not be directly evident at the moment, for this card follows the trauma of the Tower card. Remember that you hold within you all that you need for your fulfillment - the only thing that you need is courage. For this, you have all reasons to rejoice. To see this card is a message to have faith, for the universe will bless you and bring forth all that you need."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Star in the reversed position," she casually exclaims. "The Star in the reversed position means that you are feeling as though everything has turned against you. The challenges that you would normally see as exciting seem instead to make you feel as though you cannot overcome them. You have lost faith in something, whether inside yourself or with something you normally find dear."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Tower in the upright position," she casually exclaims. "The Tower in the upright position represents change in the most radical and momentous sense. It is for this reason that the card itself visually looks so unnerving. Its message is foundational, groundbreaking change... something terrible, like a disaster or a great loss."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Tower in the reversed position," she casually exclaims. "The Tower in the reversed position makes you feel some crisis looming along the horizon, and you are struggling as much as you can to try and avoid its manifestation. What you have not realized is that these breakdowns can be beneficial in breaking down your reliance on something that is false. The tower is built on faulty foundations, and it must fall, but through failure brings peace and success."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Devil in the upright position," she casually exclaims. "The Devil in the upright position shows that you have feelings of entrapment, emptiness and lack of fulfillment in your life. It might also mean that you are a slave to materialism and opulence and no matter how hard you try, you just cant seem to shake off the feeling of wanting to indulge in luxurious living."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Devil in the reversed position," she casually exclaims. "The Devil in the reversed position represents the moment when an individual becomes self-aware and breaks all of the chains that come with addiction and poor habits. It might be because they are tired of running in circles and are in need of change. One has to be prepared to make the necessary changes that might initially seem painful to make the adjustments that will pay off in the end by being able to find your true self again."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! Temperance in the upright position," she casually exclaims. "Temperance in the upright position shows that you are a person who has mastered the art of not letting things get to you, and this allows you to achieve much progress in all areas you seek out to explore. The Temperance tarot card suggests moderation and balance, coupled with a lot of patience. Where this card appears, there is the suggestion that extremity in any situation is to be avoided."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! Temperance in the reversed position," she casually exclaims. "Temperance in the reversed position is a reflection of something that is out of balance and may be causing stress and anxiety. The real meaning of the Temperance card can be deciphered using the other cards in the spread to identify areas where this imbalance is being caused. A Temperance in reversal may also be used as a warning
column3: if you take a certain path, it would lead to turbulence and excess."

column2: After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! Death in the upright position," she casually exclaims. "Death in the upright position is one of the most feared cards in a Tarot Deck, and it is very misunderstood. Many people avoid mentioning this card because it has that much power. Most times, people take the name of the card literally. However, the real meaning within the Death card is one of the most positive in the whole deck. It signals that one major phase in your life is ending, and a new one is going to start. You just need to close one door, so the new one will open. The past needs to be placed behind you, so you can focus your energy on what is ahead of you."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! Death in the reversed position," she casually exclaims. "Death in the reversed position represents change, but that you have been resisting it. You could be worried about letting go of the past, or you could not be sure of the changes that you need to make to go forward. Resisting the change and holding onto the past can limit your future, which can cause you to feel like you are in limbo. You should take some time to assess the ways that you have been approaching changes in your life. You may find you have been halting the changes that you need due to fears of the unknown."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Hanged Man in the upright position," she casually exclaims. "The Hanged Man in the upright position symbolizes a sacrifice that is needed to make in order to progress forward - whether as repentance for past wrongdoings, or a calculated step backward to recalculate his path onward. His upside down state can also symbolize the feeling of those that walk a spiritual path, for they see the world differently. Where there are others that do not understand the need to sacrifice, you see it differently. This is a natural course of action for you as you walk the path alone."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Hanged Man in the reversed position," she casually exclaims. "The Hanged Man in the reversed position represents a very specific period of time during which you feel as if you are sacrificing a significant amount of time while getting nothing in return. You might have felt as if certain things are at a state of an absolute standstill without any particular resolution or movement. Its as if you are putting your entire effort and attention into something but nothing turns out as it should."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Wheel of Fortune in the upright position," she casually exclaims. "The Wheel of Fortune in the upright position turns evermore, seemingly to communicate that life is made up of both good and bad times, and that the cycle is one that we cannot control. It is something that is subjected to both kings and workers, and that nobody on earth can avoid what is fated. When you have good moments in your life, make sure that you enjoy to the fullest, for what comes up must always go down. The same is true in reverse - when you are in a bad situation, things will eventually become better again."

After laying down the coins upon a nearby stack of books, the woman magically shuffles the deck without touching it, and proceeds to lay out the cards upon the table in a hexagonal formation, face down with one card in the middle. She goes into a spiel about my life and personal matters with each card she flips over. Lastly, she flips over the final card...\n\n"Ah! The Wheel of Fortune in the reversed position," she casually exclaims. "The Star in the reversed position means that luck has not been on your side and misfortunes have been following you. When it's associated with this card, you must understand that these are due to external influences that you cannot control. Like the wheel, our luck and our fate is always in motion, and sometimes we are on the bottom. Be assured that the wheel will turn again, and you will be okay again soon."
